p: Usually associated with interstitial diseases, reticular patterns demonstrate the thickening of interlobular and intralobular septa, presenting as linear opacities on tomography ( 11) . This is not a common finding in the initial presentations of COVID-19 and is observed in less than 22% cases ( 15, 19) , usually in later stages of the disease and preferentially in the periphery of the lungs ( 7, 17, 20) ( Figure 3A). Conversely, 20% of patients with pneumonia caused by the novel coronavirus have been reported to exhibit subpleural lines, which are nonspecific indicators of atelectasis, edema, fibrosis, or inflammation, characterized by subpleural curvilinear opacities parallel to its surface ( 11, 18) ( Figure 3B).
